title: Eliphaz’s Counsel
shortSummary: In Job chapter 5, Eliphaz the Temanite responds to Job’s lament by urging him to seek God’s help and trust in His sovereign justice. He emphasizes that suffering is part of human experience but that God disciplines the righteous for their ultimate good and delivers them from adversity.
timeline: c. 2000-1800 BC - Patriarchal Period, during the time of Job

keyCharacters.name: Eliphaz
keyCharacters.description: One of Job’s three friends who speaks in this chapter, offering counsel that suffering is a result of folly and urging Job to seek God’s correction and deliverance.

keyCharacters.name: Job
keyCharacters.description: The central figure of the book, a righteous man undergoing severe trials; he is the recipient of Eliphaz’s advice in this chapter.

definitions.definition: In this context, refers to the godly or righteous people to whom one might turn for help or counsel.
Discipline or correction from God intended to bring about repentance and spiritual growth.
Stubbornly contrary or perverse in behavior or attitude.
A dwelling place or tent; here symbolizing one’s home or life in peace and security.

outline.heading: Call for Help and Warning Against Folly
outline.description: Eliphaz challenges Job to seek help from the righteous but warns that wrath and envy destroy the foolish, illustrating the consequences of folly and injustice.

outline.heading: The Reality of Human Trouble
outline.description: Eliphaz acknowledges that trouble does not arise without cause, affirming that man is born to face difficulties as naturally as sparks fly upward.

outline.heading: Encouragement to Seek God
outline.description: Eliphaz exhorts Job to commit his cause to God, who performs marvelous deeds, provides for the earth, and protects the poor and humble from the schemes of the wicked.

outline.heading: Blessings of God’s Discipline and Deliverance
outline.description: Eliphaz teaches that God’s correction brings blessing and healing, promising deliverance from multiple troubles and a peaceful, prosperous life for those who endure His discipline.

application: When facing trials, believers should seek God’s help and trust in His sovereign care rather than relying solely on human counsel.
Christians are encouraged to view God’s discipline as a sign of His love and a means to spiritual growth, not as punishment to be despised.
Maintain hope and faith in God’s promises of deliverance and restoration even amid suffering and adversity.
Avoid envy and wrath, which lead to destruction, and instead cultivate humility and trust in God’s justice.

keyVerses.text: I would seek unto God, and unto God would I commit my cause:
keyVerses.significance: This verse highlights the proper response to suffering: turning to God in faith and entrusting Him with one’s troubles.

keyVerses.text: Behold, happy is the man whom God correcteth: therefore despise not thou the chastening of the Almighty:
keyVerses.significance: It teaches that God’s discipline is a blessing and should be embraced as a sign of His care and a path to righteousness.

keyVerses.text: He shall deliver thee in six troubles: yea, in seven there shall no evil touch thee.
keyVerses.significance: This verse assures believers of God’s protection and deliverance through multiple trials.

keyVerses.text: Thou shalt come to thy grave in a full age, like as a shock of corn cometh in in his season.
keyVerses.significance: It promises a peaceful and full life for those who endure God’s discipline and remain faithful.
